topic.title: Tox
topic.body:
Since some people here are using tox, I thought I'll join the fun and make one myself.
#What is Tox?
Tox is a decentralized encrypted instant messenger capable of voice and audio calls as well as group chats and file transfer.
#Is it safe?
Yes, each message is encrypted and the authenticity of any message is guaranteed. 
However **your IP will be visible by to the people, that you accepted as friends!**
You can get around this however, by installing tor and setting the proxy to 127.0.0.1:9050. More infos on that are available [here](https://wiki.tox.chat/users/tox_over_tor_tot).
#Where do I get Tox?
You can get Tox [here](https://tox.chat/clients.html)(clearnet), the technical specification can be seen [here](https://toktok.ltd/spec.html)(clearnet) and the source code can be seen [here](https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore)(clearnet)(this is the link to the toxcore source).

You can post your IDs here to find new friends or add those who already did.

topic.title: UFTS - A (hopefully) global tagging system for ZeroNet
topic.body:
I'm currently working on a tagging system, which I call the **U**nified **F**ixed **T**agging **S**ystem(working title, I'm open for other names).
The idea here is to make a merger hub system, that stores tags and their description. The main advantage would be, that everyone can agree on which tags mean what, on a global level and more importantly computers can do, too. Searching and finding content from all of zeronet or from a few specific zites could be done, by context(with some limitations, of course) rather than looking for phrases.

Implementation wise, so far I have this:
There are 4 data types: `tags`, `descriptions`, `description ratings` and `equality claims`:

_**tags** _ 
These are the tags, nothing much to say here, really. Tags are stored inside a tags.json. They have:
- `tag content`, which is the plain text of the tag('female:smiling', for example)
- `tag-id`, which is the sha256-hash of the *tag content*, this eliminates duplicates across all hubs.
-  `date added`, which is the date when the tag was added(because we are is a decentralized system, this date should be taken with a grain of salt, as everyone can fake it without much effort).

The hub, they are on and the user that posted them are inferred by the json table, that zeronet generates from the content.json, this way no user can, intentionally or not, just change the origin of a tag this is also true for all other data types, so I won't mention it again.

_**descriptions**_
They describe a tag. Every user can write descriptions for any tag in any hub. A description can only ever be for one tag, but a single tag can have multiple descriptions. Each description has:
- `description content`, which is the plain text of the description('Someone female, that is seen smiling.', for example).
- `description-id`, which is an uuidv4. It uniquely identifies each description.
- `tag reference id`, which is the id of the tag, that that description belongs to.
-  `date added`, which is the date when the description was added(because we are is a decentralized system, this date should be taken with a grain of salt, as everyone can fake it without much effort).

_**description ratings**_
Since everyone can post descriptions, we need some kind of way to tell which descriptions are good and which aren't. This is exactly that. Each rating is stored as an integer, that can either be positive or negative. The actual interpretation is open for the zite developer to choose. By default these rules will apply: 0=won't be counted, everything positive=+1 Vote and everything negative=-1Vote the sum of all votes makes the rating of a description. A description rating has:
- `reference description id`, which is the id of the description that is being rated.
- `rating`, which is an integer that can range from negative infinity to positive infinity.
-  `date added`, which is the date when the rating was added(because we are is a decentralized system, this date should be taken with a grain of salt, as everyone can fake it without much effort).

_**equality claims**_
This addresses the issue that some tags can mean the same thing. Any user can issue a equality claim, that means he picks two tags and claims, that both are equal. An equality claim has:
- `reference tag id 1`, which is one of the two tags that the user claimed were equal.
- `reference tag id 2`, which is the other tag.
-  `date added`, which is the date when the equality claim was added(because we are is a decentralized system, this date should be taken with a grain of salt, as everyone can fake it without much effort).

The UFTS is separated in a merger zite, private and public hubs:
- merger zite: Here you can browse all tags, that you currently have access to, (think of it like [ZeroName](/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/)). It doesn't store anything.
- private hubs: Here only the owner of the hub can create new tags, but everyone can add descriptions, rate and make equality claims.
- public hubs: Here everyone can add tags, descriptions, ratings and make equality claims.

Interacting with the UFTS will be done through an js library or the database directly(accessing the merger zite over CORS), if the zite developer want's more fine grained control.
  
  
This is what I have so far. What do you think? If you have improvements or other ideas? Please, do not hesitate to tell me. I'm still experimenting with things and POC-ing stuff, so there is not any code public, yet. But if anyone want's to contribute I'll make a gitcenter repo and put, what I have so far there.

topic.title: [Dev]Recursive objects in dbschema.json?
Using a BitTorrent client to download ZeroNet files?
topic.body:
As stated above it it possible to construct a magnet link/`.torrent` file from a file hosted on ZeroNet?
That file/link could then be given to people that don't have ZeroNet, but a regular BitTorrent client instead, such that they would be able to also seed/get that one file hosted on ZeroNet. This should vastly improve seeders for various files and would make for an effortless way to get a taste of ZeroNet without having to install anything.

topic.title: The zite SQLite Database Dump tool
topic.body:
I made a single HTML page tool, that will display all contents of the sqlite database of the zite.  
  
The source is available on [Git Center](../1us6a7ZNRRwJsq3Dwaho1TijtjSAVbNYg) and consists of only a single html file, that can be copy/pasted anywhere within your zite. To see the database simply navigate to where you pasted the file in your zite with your browser.  
  
This is meant as a debug tool for zite developers and not for the average user.  
  
  
Improvements/bug reports/contributions and so on are welcomed and greatly appreciated.
If you have any questions feel free to ask me.

1538246886_1MHdmQEW2HS6sZNgfi3VmtegHc6fU.body:
In a nutshell, zeronet restricts zites inside iframes, that have only limited permissions. In theory any js(=javascript) on any zite should not be able to do anything shady. 
**However**: js is packed with vulnerabilities, which could and have(in the past) broken through the iframe sandbox and through the browser itself. Also one has to keep in mind even if the js were to be perfectly safe, there are plugins you might have installed(such as flash for example), that can communicate freely using your ip and to whatever server they desire. Js is definitively the most insecure part of zeronet at the moment and the fact that you are required to have js enabled at all times is scary, especially since zite owners are basically gods(in the sense, that they can do anything they want on their zite, including banning and deleting users). At the moment it is impossible to have communication in zeronet without js, since communication with the zeronet client is not possible as soon as you use the /raw/-prefix(/raw/ is the only way you can have access to a zite without js, which, at the current point in time, breaks all zites, that have some sort of communication feature and most other zites, that don't since they rely on js for building the html for the webpage).

> [zeropyro](#comment_21_1KsFe6vgVpNFCNTQDQryrcQYySkAbFLXCV): This is a bitcoin miner and not a virus!
I don't agree with that. A cryptominer is basically stealing your electricity and converting it into digital currency. This is where cryptocurrencies get their intrinsic value from, you trade electric bills(and time) into the currency you're mining. Which is why anti virus software defends you from that.
Edit: In addition to (depending on implementation) a cryptominer will make connections to normal websites outside of zeronet, to query it's blockchain, pool or pending transactions for data to include in the mined block.

> [zeropyro](#comment_22_1KsFe6vgVpNFCNTQDQryrcQYySkAbFLXCV): It is not mandatory to use the page.You are paying with this for the content.
This is true, but one does not have to inform the user, that a cryptominer is used, furthermore most users won't even know what it means to have a cryptominer running in the background in the first place. Without the user being aware of the fact, that they are paying with their electricity. Much like a C&C virus, in theory there is nothing wrong with having your computer part of a botnet and the user would probably don't mind either, but without the user knowing(or having control over it in a certain way), still makes it a virus. This is what differentiates having zeronet installed from being part of a botnet. 
The issue of clearnet connections still remains.

> [nekololi](#comment_269_1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB): such wisdom! do you have any other predictions to give us?
*In my infinite omnipotence I shall predict that in no more than 12 full moons there will be the next one to be unveiled.*

But jokes aside, js is a huge security issue. There are so many ways you can do one thing and so many things that you, as a developer, just didn't think about. I mean look at google, twitter or facebook. All of them are multi billion dollar companies, that have thousands of highly capable(and paid) developers and on all of them had at some point security breaking js vulnerabilities.
Personally, js is almost as bad as C. The only way, I js could be even worse, than it already is, would be to have pointers and custom memory allocation in there.
In my opinion, that it is impossible to have any non-static zites without js, is the single most biggest issue zeronet has right now. I don't have a ~~microsoft~~ github account to open an issue there, but I made [this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:137:Changelog:+September+21,+2018#comment_1_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC) post on ZeroBlog, I would be grateful if someone could open an issue for me.

1542278485_1ELQXPkiUPmfR2ZCJLyhEucP5vqkL.body: QubesOS. Can't get anymore reasonably secure than that.

> [zeroforze](#comment_5_1MH6Mx8cxRRWFZEckKc8tztJGDyEBzri8H): Now that is a quite cool approach. How is the graphics performance, if for example one want to run 3d applications or games?
You'll need a good computer to run it. I'd say it eats RAM for breakfast, but saying that it eats chromes for breakfast would be more accurate. A fast SSD is also a necessity, a HDD will work, but be prepared to wait minutes for an program to start. A fast processor and/or crypto module is also really beneficial.
If you have an nvidia graphics card be ready to be in a world of hurt, since their drivers refuse to work in the cubes themselves and on some of the newer ones it might not work for Qubes at all.
Running 3d will be a challenge, since hardware acceleration is disabled(for good reasons, security wise).

Qubes is really not the OS you should be facing toward, if you want to play games(at least not yet). It will however make your computer an nearly unpenetrable fortress to any virus, hackers and even state level actors.

> [1pgallery](#comment_10_1GDcCK6cWoj98mg541Yj9rW1nwXcBz87eE): Also: we on Git Center now! 
Nice!
Some ideas I had for 0gallery some time ago:
- There should be a set of predefined(default) tags available and it should be possible to add custom tags, that are separate from the default ones. Think of it like having tag hubs, one that can only be altered by the owner of 1+gallery(this will contain the default ones) and one that anyone can submit new tags.
- The tagging of galleries should be separated into user tags and creator tags and than have an option in the config to either merge both, only use the user tags or only use the creator tags, when searching. This will prevent possible tagging scams(overtagging or falsetagging).
- Tag descriptions, that are build the same way as the tags. The tag creator can provide his own description, but users can still submit their own descriptions and vote them. The highest voted one will be displayed, when the mouse is hovered above the tag, with an option to see other definitions. Users can also choose to only respect tag-creator descriptions, only respect user descriptions or both(in this case maybe have the creator description have a vote of '10' and as soon as an user description surpasses that it will be the displayed one(maybe then also make the 'creator vote threshold' changeable in the config))
- Maybe add a category system, like sadpanda, where a gallery can either be manga, comic, images or images with captions (the fact, that there is no clear distinction on sadpanda is beyond annoying)
- Make a tag-voting system, where users can vote whether or not a tag is fit for that gallery. Like sadpanda does it
- Make two separate kinds of hubs one that is private, where only the owner can add galleries and one public, where everyone can upload galleries. This is probably a point for the [1+Hub](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1543026395_1GDcCK6cWoj98mg541Yj9rW1nwXcBz87eE/GalleryHub+Demo) thread, but I'll also put it here since it kind of fits.
- Make it possible to vote/rate galleries.
- Make a button to download(I mean a .zip download in the browser) any given gallery.
- Add the ability to download and save(as in browser download) any image in the gallery by the click of an button(maybe middle mouse click?). This will be really helpful for browsing imageset dumps.

A feature to keep track of what you have started watching and where you stopped watching would be really nice. No site (that I know) has this feature and it is **really** handy, if you don't want to have around 1000 tabs open to remind you what you havn't finished watching, yet.

> [1pgallery](#comment_27_1GDcCK6cWoj98mg541Yj9rW1nwXcBz87eE): I'm thinking of making a public hub that anyone can upload to using their zeroid/kxoid/etc. but that will take a while.

When you are doing this, please consider what I wrote [in the other thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1542671496_1GDcCK6cWoj98mg541Yj9rW1nwXcBz87eE/Announcing+1+Gallery+an+updated+ZeroGallery+Merger#comment_29_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC), as most of these features are easiest to add in the early stages of development.  
Most of the features I described there, are (in my opinion) crucial to ensure that a hub can run in a (somewhat) moderated manner, without requiring anyone to actually do the moderating(or in other words a self correcting system). This is necessary to keep the hub decentralized, which will grantee that a (theoretical) moderator cannot destroy the hub, if he feels like it(or has a bad day) and keep the hub running long after the (theoretical) moderator left ZeroNet for whatever reason(avoid abandoned/unmaintained hubs).

I think a freenet-ish solution would be best: Have any file in ZeroNet encrypted with, let's say, the hash of it's content and some local secret(maybe a hash of the private key of the uploader?) as the key. If a zite needs to display the file, it has to get the key, which is associated with the hash of the encrypted file, first and can only then access the file. This way, it is possible(again, like in freenet) for the user to allocate some amount of space to a zite he wants to support, that ZeroNet will use to download and seed files(probably those with few seeders) for some time(preferably random) before overwriting it with another poorly seeded file, so you never share the same file for a long amount of time.
Note: this does make the assumption, that most of the files are not of legally difficult content, which will be fine for ZeroNet and similar, but can get difficult, if you get to more let's say explicit zites.

Since you can't know what the file contains, you should be fine in most jurisdictions.
The decryption keys you have could be tossed after each time you close ZeroNet and be redownloaded once you start ZeroNet. The whole time, you'll be sharing all decryption keys you discover while you're browsing ZeroNet to as many peers as you can(key are small, so the overhead will be neglegeable), which will legally fine, too since the key to a probably illegal(remember, you only know that this key will decrypt a file with some hash, you cannot know what that file was before encryption) file is not the illegal file an thus not an issue.

> [klu9](#comment_31_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Not an expert here, just wondering about how this system would deal with languages: e.g. if an image of a cat is tagged with the English word "cat", would it be found by a Spanish speaker searching for "gato" or a Chinese speaker for "猫"?

Yes. The 'equality claims' I described above are made specifically to catch those kind of redundancy issues. Any user can publicly claim that two tags are equal to one another(that's why I called them 'equality claims').

How that could look like in action is:
Our english user A trusts user B. Because user B speaks both spanish and chinese as well as english, he makes the equality claims, that "gato"="cat" and "cat"="猫". If user A now searches for anything tagged with "cat" he will fist look if any of his trusted friends made an equality claim, that involves "cat". With that he will make a list of tags, that are considered equal and find all posts that have (at least one) tag, that is also present in that list.

Having each user maintain a 'trusted users' list is not the most practical solution, but sybil attacks are unfortunately really good attacks. If you have a good idea on how to defend this equality claim system against bad actors/spammers feel free to tell me. I've been thinking for quite some time about this and what I outlined in [this](#comment_45_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC) comment is the best I came up with.

Oh, I forgot to update the main post(will do that at some point in the future). I think I already wrote this somewhere, but the way it is set up right now is that you have:
- namespaces
- namespace definitions
- namespace equality claims
- tags
- tag definitions
- tag equality claims

So what you would see on a zite would be `namespace:tag_name` for example `language:english` or `female:smile`.
Where tag and namespace definitions as well as the equality claims for both can be rated (voted `+1`,`0`,`-1`) by other users. The highest number of positive votes indicating the 'official' definition and in the case of equality claims must surpass a (configurable) threshold in order to be valid.

A whitelisting system is also an intended way to further restrict bad actors, but that will have to be implemented by the zite dev since he needs to manage the list of bad users for his zite. There is also the distinction between private and public hubs, where on private hubs users can only make equality claims, definitions and vote on those but not add new tags or namespaces(only the owner that some people the owner chooses can do that)

1549791989_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
You try to look up `json_id` in the `user` table, this won't work.
`json_id` is an automatically generated row by zeronet and links users and their content on each table together.
`json_id` can be understood as a reference to the content.json of the user, that something else belongs to.
ZeroNet generates the `json` table which contains all the corresponding values to the `json_id` reference, such as `site`(=hub), `directory`, `file_name`, `cert_auth_type` and so on.
Doing:
```
select * from json where json_id is '4439'
```
should work as expected.
For some deeper understanding, I would suggest to install something that allows you to see into `.db` files or take a look at the [dbschema.json](/1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH/dbschema.json) of ZeroMe

> [leftside](#comment_570_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): But Why some IDs still work with from user table??

Because ZeroNet also generates these references for the `user` table(in fact ZeroNet generates them for every table in every database). Since the `json_id`s are counted up, you'll find that especially the lower(so `json_id`=1 or 44 or 853 for example) ones will be on there by chance. They most likely won't point to the same user, though. The reason for that is how exactly ZeroNet generates these references.

> [kaffie](#comment_793_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): 

I haven't really had a good look at cjdns/yggdrasil, so I cant really tell you where the differences are in those and i2p, but I can tell you about the difference of TOR and I2P.
In a nutshell: Tor makes TCP connections anonymous; I2p makes UDP connections anonymous.
As a reminder: 
- TCP: Think of it like tunnels your computer and the computer you want to connect to. Building the tunnel is difficult and requires a lot of work on both sides, but once the tunnel is done sending messages through that tunnel is a bliss. There is no traffic that interferes with your message(it's fast), you message is guaranteed to reach the other side and you know what path you message took.
- UDP: Think of it like the public mail. If you want to send a message from A to B you write a letter and give it to the mailman, who delivers your letter to B. However he takes his time, takes takes a different path to B for every message you send and might just loose your message altogether.

So TCP is optimal if you need to send a lot of messages to **one** other computer
and UDP is optimal if you need to send a lot of messages to **many different** computers.
 
Since torrent makes lots of small messages to lots of computers UDP is the better protocol for that, and thus I2P would be the better choice as an anonymity layer.
Due to the way TOR and I2P work:
- Lots of TOR connections weaken your anonymity (in some cases immensely)
- Lots of TOR connections will slow down the entire TOR network, effectively DDOSing it.
- Few TOR connections strengthen your anonymity (in most cases immensely)
- Few TOR connections will make the entire TOR network faster.

In contrast:
- Lots of I2P connections strengthen your anonymity
- Lots of I2P connections will speed up and benefit the entire I2P network.
- Few I2P connections weaken your anonymity (in most cases immensely)
- Few I2P will make the entire I2P network slower.

Related to this, to access the I2P network, one needs to have the I2P router running. Your speed on I2P and anonymity increases with the amount of time that you router is online, this lines up pretty nicely with ZeroNet, which is also best for everyone if left online for 24/7.


The ~~long~~ technical, but still simplified version:
##TOR
TOR stands for **T**he **O**nion **R**outer and builds on the idea that you messages are send, tucked in layers of encryption and then send through some chosen computers, that can each only read one layer of encryption. The computer the message was intended to will recognize this because it is the first computer in the chain that can actually read the message, instead of just seeing a 'send here next' and random encrypted data.
assume you want to send message "Hi bob" to bob through TOR, you first need to choose the computers you want your message to go through let's say you chose computers `A`,`B` and `C`. What you now do is you message each of them and get their public key. You then choose the order in which the chosen computers should be messaging each other in this case we want `You->A->B->C->bob` and begin the construction of you TOR message. You first leave instructions on what `C` should do with the message and then encrypt your message with the public key of `C`, so only C can read that message, `C("send this to 123.231.132.213;" + "Hi bob")`, which would (for example) be equal to: ` "1CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"`. Now, since you want `B` to be before `C`, you take that scrambled(encrypted) text, include instructions what `B` should do with it and encrypt those, such that only `B` can read it, `B("send this to C;" + "1CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG")`, which would (for example) be equal to: `1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8`. Now, since you want `A` to come before `B`, you do that same as before: leave instructions for `A` and encrypt the message, `A("send this to B;" + "1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"`, which would (for example) be equal to: `1K3tM7irQqSX4Hx3JvNgkimkQzY6jPtBfz`. And just like that you are done. You now only need to send `1K3tM7irQqSX4Hx3JvNgkimkQzY6jPtBfz` to `A` and bob will receive your message.
Here is how you, `A`, `B`, `C` and bob will see your communication.
1. [you] send `"1K3tM7irQqSX4Hx3JvNgkimkQzY6jPtBfz"` to `A`
2. [A] receive `"1K3tM7irQqSX4Hx3JvNgkimkQzY6jPtBfz"`
3. [A] can I decrypt this with my private key?
4. [A] I have `"send this to B;" + "1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"` now
5. [A] no idea what `"1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"` means, but I know what to do with `send this to B`.
6. [A] send `1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8` to `B`
7. [B] I only know that you gave me something I don't understand and that I should send that to `B`
8. [B] receive `"1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"`
9. [B] can I decrypt this with my private key?
10. [B] I have `"send this to C;" + "1CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"` now
11. [B] no idea what `"1CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"` means, but I know what to do with `send this to C`.
12. [B] send `1CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG` to `C`
13. [B] I only know that `A` gave me something I don't understand and that I should send that to `C`
14. [C] receive `"1CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"`
15. [C] can I decrypt this with my private key?
16. [C] I have `"send this to 123.231.132.213;" + "Hi bob"` now
17. [C] know and can log what `"Hi bob"` means, but there is also this instruction I understand `send this to 123.231.132.213`.
18. [C] send `"Hi bob"` to `123.231.132.213`
19. [C] I know the content of the message and where it should go to.
20. [bob] receive `"Hi bob"`
21. [bob] neat, but I only know that `C` send me this.

As you can see, no one knows who the message originated from since no one can know, if you made the message or if you just did what `A` and `B` did.
However you might also be able to see that `C` is able to read your message, the reason for that is that bob and you didn't encrypt your message. If you send a message over the TOR network and that message leaves the TOR network, that it must leave the TOR network in a way that 'outsiders' can understand, if you and bob chose not to encrypt your message then it must be delivered in decrypted form to him, with makes the last computer within the TOR network(one could call it an `exit node`) able to read your message and because `C` is the one that sends it to bob he also knows who bob is.
How do you solve this? Well one way is to tell bob to use the TOR network as well, so that the message never leaves the TOR network. In this case, this is how you, `A`, `B`, `C` and bob will see your communication.
1. [you] send `"K3tM7irQqSX4Hx3JvNgkimkQzY6jPtBfz"` to `A`
2. [A] receive `"K3tM7irQqSX4Hx3JvNgkimkQzY6jPtBfz"`
3. [A] can I decrypt this with my private key?
4. [A] I have `"send this to B;" + "N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"` now
5. [A] no idea what `"N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"` means, but I know what to do with `send this to B`.
6. [A] send `1N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8` to `B`
7. [B] I only know that you gave me something I don't understand and that I should send that to `B`
8. [B] receive `"N6zp6jCXPBktNMPfe7UJBpQGyfCq7k2M8"`
9. [B] can I decrypt this with my private key?
10. [B] I have `"send this to C;" + "CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"` now
11. [B] no idea what `"CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"` means, but I know what to do with `send this to C`.
12. [B] send `CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG` to `C`
13. [B] I only know that `A` gave me something I don't understand and that I should send that to `C`
14. [C] receive `"CufK1ZtvekbFXEpSyKT2gDjf9jnqW8KwG"`
15. [C] can I decrypt this with my private key?
16. [C] I have `"send this to bob;" + "Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba"` now
17. [C] no idea what `"Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba"` means, but I know what to do with `send this to bob`.
18. [C] send `"Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba"` to `bob`
19. [C] I know the content of the message and where it should go to.
20. [C] I only know that `B` gave me something I don't understand and that I should send that to bob
21. [bob] receive `"Mr5rX9TauvaGReB4RjCaE6D37FJQaY5Ba"`
22. [bob] can I decrypt this with my private key?
23. [bob] I have `"Hi bob"` now
24. [bob] neat, but I only know that `C` send me this.

Now `C` doesn't know that bob was the destination and has no idea what the contents of the message were. 
We have just (in a simplified form) invented `.onion` addresses.

##I2P
I2P is based not on onion routing, but on garlic routing, a modified version of onion routing. Basic communication structure is the similar, but each new computer that receives your message can append another message to it, before it sends it to the next one, such that a single I2P message contains multiple messages from different people to different people (like a garlic, wrapped in layers and containing many 'things' on the inside). I2P messages are also not send from one computer to another, but from one computer to possibly many.

For more details I can only highly encourage you to check out the wikipedia page for [TOR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tor_%28anonymity_network%29)(Clearnet) and [I2P](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I2P)(Clearnet)

1552916412_1GDzVsFoYamHqWcYBcuvVWFCAt3Y5.body:
> [deliriumgoddess6](#comment_8_1GDzVsFoYamHqWcYBcuvVWFCAt3Y5yPNde): i`ve seen that video. so its really safer than tor even?

Depends on what you are using it for. I explained that in more detail in [this](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1550688425_1Axcs3zkrrpHhBAAZMUhXEQZ4z6ahqqaS6) thread
In a very broad stroke: Yes, since Tor relies on central hardcoded trusted servers, while I2P does not. However Tor has a (comparatively) massive budget, state level interest in staying anonymous and (in contrast to many opensource projects) a large number of random people who actually check and audit the source code regularly. The Tor network is also more used and (mainstream)popular then I2P, which improves plausible deniability if you get v&.

> [satoxyn1](#comment_18_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPxGe2Zq): This is hoax. When Tor developers say that Tor should not be used with Bittorrent, they refer to usual Bittorrent clients which will connect only to clearnet nodes, hurting Exit Node bandwidth.

With tor you are not using one circuit for all connections. The usual circuit has 3 nodes, all in series. This means all data you send and receive will go through all these nodes for all circuits you use to torrent. Since the download is split among many circuits that are all likely to be performed with the max bandwidth per connection of the weakest node blocking these off from other nodes. Also, because tcp the connection creation is computationally expensive and takes time, it will (to some extend) block the node you're currently using from making other circuits. Circuits being frequently created and destroyed(say if you have many frequently changing connections), effectively DDOSes the network. Both hurt(and slow down) the network.  

Also the more connections(circuits) you make, the easier and stronger correlation and sybil attacks become, this hurts your anonymity.  

It is not a hoax, there are good reasons not to torrent over Tor.

1553166302_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPx.body:
> [nekololi](#comment_349_1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXehoNAB): why merely threaten the user with giving their ip and info over to authorities, rather than just fucking doing it?

Probably because they wouldn't have anything on him. Europol or not(and since there is that "depending on your network"(no mention of DC++) this probably isn't even an Europol thing), international stuff is always complicated, since your evidence needs to be approved by the country where it was found(to some extend) and the country where you are in, in order to have any legal strength and even then it can be difficult since court rulings of both countries would need to back this transfer of evidence(since the country you live would have to blindly trust, that the police agency from the other country isn't lying about/crafting the logs they have against you) in order for that to happen. 
  
And all that is assuming that there even is real evidence. Different countries have different thresholds as to when you are guilty or not. Additionally whether or not  you actually had the intention or not(provocative file names are enough to indicate intention for some countries but all) to actually download CP doesn't even matter, because in many countries you need to actually have possessed CP in order to be guilty of anything. The police would need to spend a considerable amount of time, resources and money even finding out which of these if the case not to mention all that across possibly multiple boarders. That can take months, if not weeks depending on the effort you made to keep you safe. And all that is needed to find just one single offender, that may still go completely free for one or more of the other reasons I mentioned above. 1557421253_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBj.body:
>is using Tor Browser with Tor enabled really important on ZeroNet / good enough to feel safe ?

Yes, not only do you feel more safe, you actually are. The TBB forces website/zite traffic through the Tor network. Zites on zeronet can make requests to clearnet servers(due to the way js is build) and as soon as a zite makes connection to any clearnet site, that site knows your ip address and (depending on implementation) also maybe that you came from zeronet, if the referrer was set(for example to 127.0.0.1:43110). ZeroID, for example, sends the data that needs to be signed to a server that knows the zeroID signing key. That server is a clearnet server and if you didn't use the TBB that server now knows your ip. ZeroBoard was made like this as well.
Also the TBB does a lot of stuff behind the scenes to make tracking you as hard as possible.  
  
TL;DR, yes it is important.

Also please keep in mind money **always** leaves traces. If someone targets you, you need crazy good OPsec to remain anonymous if you paid money(cash) to anyone **once**. Even things like Bitcoin that don't belong to you identity are hard to get hold of (and spend) in an anonymous way.

> [chinchin](#comment_3_18HYVwCAgri1SgiYZcEZMehKoXZo6Eg7im): true but that means that you would need to get a second graphics card

You don't need a good graphics card. Qubes really doesn't need much GPU power. An SSD and fast CPU are a much bigger factor.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_300_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): But if your home is accessing the TOR network, then your data coming out of the VPN gateway is bound for the three hop encrypted journey to the final destination. No?

Yes. Over TOR it there are these possibilities:
1 VPN before TOR:
[YourHome] -> `YourData` -> Encryption -> `43fAOy36` => [VPN_Provider] -> decrypt -> `YourData` => [TOR_Relay#1] => [TOR_Relay#2] => [TOR_Relay#3] => [Internet]
2 VPN after TOR:
[YourHome] -> `YourData` -> Encryption -> `43fAOy36` => [TOR_Relay#1] => [TOR_Relay#2] => [TOR_Relay#3] => [VPN_Provider] -> decrypt -> `YourData` => [Internet]  
  
Your VPN provider can basically be considered to be a '''TOR_Relay''' that knows who you are and what you want to access at what time, that you pay them to keep your identity safe. A TLA would need to work from `[Internet]` backwards to find you. That means that if you have VPN before TOR, the VPN becomes your last line of defense and one more hurdle to finding you. If you have VPN after TOR, however then the first thing they see is a VPN which you have paid money to this will be used to find you nearly instantly. You basically reduce the anonymity to the anonymity of your VPN(barely nothing at all). Also in option 2 your VPN provider can see the cleartext of what you sent and received, whereas in the first option they can only see random TOR traffic..

1559711646_1w9czsVapAVmVVQzf7xzuSqvqGar6.body:
All links are to clearnet.
ZeroNet is depends on the bitcoin crypto be remain intact(usable), that means [ECDSA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_DSA) crypto and the [Secp256k1](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Secp256k1) curve need to be safe, since that is what's being used to sign and publish files on here. Unfortunately, like most things, it is absolutely destroyed by Quantum computers. Specifically a modification of [shor's algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor%27s_algorithm)(the one that breaks the prime factorization based RSA encryption) has [already been made](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_curve_cryptography#Quantum_computing_attacks) that can [efficiently solve](https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/33069/why-is-ecc-more-vulnerable-than-rsa-in-a-post-quantum-world) the [discrete logarithm problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_logarithm#Cryptography), which is the bases for elliptic curve cryptography(that's what the EC stands for in ECDSA). So yeah, really bad news for ZeroNet, since whoever has the private key of a zite, which a quantum computer can compute from only a signature and a public key, can decide what content the zite shows or in other words censor it or take it down. What makes this even worse is, that while there are many [cryptography proposals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-quantum_cryptography), that are believed to be 'quantum secure', they all are either not proven(formally analyzed) to actually work or **way** to slow/big to be viable in use. AFAIK a good post-quantum cryptography algorithm is still subject of heavy academic research. TOR will also be [hit by this](https://tor.stackexchange.com/questions/4649/does-tor-team-have-plans-to-implement-post-quantum-asymmetrical-encryption-schem) **really hard** basically granting one the ability to(with reasonable effort) break TOR circuits and deanonymize you([Tor design](https://svn.torproject.org/svn/projects/design-paper/tor-design.html), [Tor specs](https://gitweb.torproject.org/torspec.git/tree/tor-spec.txt)). To the best of my knowledge I2P will also take a hit from this but still provide you with reasonable plausible deniability.

On the subject of crypto/blockchains: It really depends on the design of the protocol, but in case of Bitcoin the damage done is not too high, since the BTC blockchain relies on a game of chance based on computational strength only, that in turn relies on the unpredictableness of a sha-hash, which is not currently known to be predictable(forgeable) by Quantium computing. So past transactions and blockchain integrity are safe. Satoshi thankfully had the foresight to have the public key to your private walled address hashed before it becomes your regular bitcoin address so your bitcoins you have received and send are also save(in theory). But if you ever signed anything with your bitcoin address and someone were to get hold of that signature and the public key(or possibly just multiple signatures) ever at some point in time will be able to just take all your bitcoins.

TL;DR: Everything will be hit really hard once big quantum computers come around, as a **rule of thumb** the security of your crypto will be cut in half, if it's not broken entirely, by specific quantum algorithms. So a 256-bit AES key will have the strength of an 128-bit AES key against a quantum computer

> [fantoski](#comment_52_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBjgo6j3): Holy fuck I'm next-level retarded.  [...]
You can also use `CHECK` in the `tables`-section for really fine grained control over what is accepted into the db as id.
For example this: `text NOT NULL UNIQUE CHECK(tag_ID NOT GLOB '*[^a-z^A-Z^0-9]*' AND length(tag_ID) BETWEEN 1 AND 43 )` is what I use in UFTS to check tagIDs(which are base62 encoded 256-bit blake hashes) before they are added to the db. Any tag_ID that doesn't fit this criteria will not be added to anyone's database.

1562000931_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
>as collaborators to the GitHub repository

How much to rely a on the (very) centralized (and not to mention owned by © Microsoft®™ now) GitHub is also a consideration to be made.

---

There is also the issue that giving the private keys to the most critical zites on ZeroNet to the multiple owners will cause problems, since owners will have to join and leave that state and once they know the private keys we cannot ensure that that person will just dispose of it. This makes changing any member a huge security risk. 

---

Also as was noted before: OPsec is actually really not that easy(there is a lot of subtlety) and adding more owners(while leaving the current infrastructure as is) will in the best case scenario have all members have better OPsec then Nofish(so everything stays how it is now) or have at least one member with worse OPsec then him in which case it just got easier to compromise everything. Rotating the address for ZeroHello(for example) frequently or implement a feature that requires 4 of of 5 signatures in a content.json to update a critical zite might be a good idea to somewhat combat that, but seem a bit hacky to me.

---

>what group of people should actually have the rights to rule the network

There is also a consideration to be made as to what group of people should get into that position.
People that have the best intentions for ZeroNet vs 'good' or even fair people.
Making that based on vote size could result in a ZeroNet staff you might really not like(and that also really don't like each other), for ethical/personal reasons.
Two examples would be:
- ZeroNet gets popular and nazis come flooding in. Since they tend to be more active then everyone else the voting activity(or just brute numbers) will crush all competition when it comes to voting.
- ZeroNet has already made some waves in the pedo community, so it's not unreasonable that a (or multiple) pedos will become 'heads of ZeroNet', which isn't a problem in on itself but having the group with the worst possible reputation to be the face of the project would be a challenge, to say the least. Also pedos tend to be raided fairly often for little to no applicable reason, so unless there is good OPsec the risk of the private key falling into the hands of a state is definitely high.

---

1565661379_13Gu27WksygoMQzLpktTGzZTHumTN.body:
> [08admin](#comment_7_1KSUcqHRcq26pF5vJ2297jrNcAzkNvLtSH): We're working on it now.  The Millchan developer actually has a Git repository with code for fixing this exact issue and we're trying to figure out how to implement it. [...]

It would be a good idea to look at the repo (at a state before the switch to typescript happened, if you're unfamiliar with typescript) and see how the image upload has been done. Don't focus on specific commits, since there were things in that regard that got fixed and added later on, in a nutshell:
- You need to resize the image in JS (in the case of millchan `jimp` is used)
- The resizing should be done in a separate thread(worker) or it will bring your webrowser to a crashing halt, if you try to upload an image > 400KB
- The problem with workers: All zites live in iframes, that due to zeronets design, must not give the 'allow-same-origin' permission in the iframe sandbox. Because of that workers cannot load any js files, since the browser makes special urls for those files before loading them from this generated url.
- As a workaround all workers must load their js files from a blob and a blob url. This means all used libraries as well as the js itself must be gathered in string form, appended to each other in the correct order, converted to a blob and then converted to an blob url.
- If you have the base64 data you need to upload it to the zeronet client. Look at `files.js` and `millchan.js#uploadBigFiles(...)` as well as the [ZeroNet Docs](/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#bigfileuploadinit) on that.

Is there a specific reason why you don't want to upgrade 08chan to the latest version?

> [08admin](#comment_8_1KSUcqHRcq26pF5vJ2297jrNcAzkNvLtSH): Some of our users did a test update of their local clients, and many of them developed errors and massive slowdown. 

The errors are probably due to the hacky way they updated 08chan. There is a massive slowdown on Tor Browser(TBB) due to the lexical parser(does the markup) and a runtime performance penalty for vue(the display library used in millchan and 08chan). The runtime penalty should be the same on 08chan and millchan, with TBB getting worse performance compared to FF(because TBB throttles js and hardware acceleration to obfuscate the kind of hardware your computer has). I dumped a few of my test results on [this](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/12NPW6WLFBLVivNGqijcfktARobftfLFAN:dev:b79fce8b-df0d-4ab4-a89e-4c37585aa6d1#post-22063759-44aa-403e-83c5-719bb8887a22) millchan/dev/ thread if you're interested on more metrics.

I'm actually currently writing a fix for the performance issue with the lexical parser. Looking at a 4-times speedup of loading threads/posts on TBB. 

>There's also mistrust of the merger system giving board owners moderation powers. 

millchan merger(technically called `millchan engine`) and millchan are completely separate zites.
- http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA - Millchan
- http://127.0.0.1:43110/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC - Millchan Engine

As a side note: I would for the time being refrain from using millchan engine, because the are things that need to be done that might require to break backwards compatibility with older hubs. Consider millchan engine a PoC and nothing more.
>Our circumstances are rather different than Millchan's proper.

I can't really judge that, but keep in mid that zite owners are basically gods. That turns them into massive centralized points of failure. Security implications aside, it makes have 08chan a bus factor of 1; If you are or get compromised, everyone is. The hub/merger system distributes that power over the content of a zite.

That is the Vue issue I was talking about. Millchan currently uses Vue2, Vue3 is currently being developed and said to be released sometime this year. It promises numerous performance improvements across the board, but unfortunately doesn't fix the issue we are dealing with.

> [512](#comment_17_18JjtihTHzagQ7Ut2j4w9x6aB159JKCRu3): Also test thumbnail image generation when posting mp4/webm, or anything else which generates thumbnails. Even updated Millchan will output empty canvas for mp4 thumbnails when using TBB, unless you disable resistFingerprinting stuff.

This is a longstanding known bug. There isn't really a fast js library that we can use to extract images(we need to use js for that because we can't extract data from the canvas-element).
Put in simple words(slightly inaccurate): Javascript is slow, posing images on TBB(Tor Browser Bundle) is already really slow, imagine the abysmal speeds something that would be ~20 images per second for multiple seconds.

See [this](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/12NPW6WLFBLVivNGqijcfktARobftfLFAN:dev:b79fce8b-df0d-4ab4-a89e-4c37585aa6d1) millchan /dev/ thread for more info.

Perhaps, we are still evaluating stuff. I'm playing with the idea to make a ZeroNet plugin to do these conversions in python to offload the performance penalty to a faster language. This will be optional, of course, with fallback to the javascript processing if the plugin is not installed. I'm still looking into it, though.

>Some did report not all 3 are needed -

You only need `privacy.resistFingerprinting`. `privacy.resistFingerprinting.autoDeclineNoUserInputCanvasPrompts` will only hide the canvas fingerprint warning popup that is(since TBB 8.0) not triggered anyways for JS that runs in an iframe(which all zites do). and `services.sync.prefs.sync.privacy.resistFingerprinting` is (as far as I know) just a flag that tells TBB to sync the `resistFingerprinting` behavior to other browsers you connected through Mozillas sync service.

 >Side question, you mentioned TBB is throttling JS, and a fix for lexical parser. Is there any setting in TBB to turn the throttling off?

As far as I know that is one of the changes made in the codebase of TBB and not a configuration thing. So no, that is impossible. With the most recent updates of millchan source code this shouldn't be an issue anymore. Lazy loading and other techneques have reduced the **apparent** thread loading times from 45 seconds on TBB to about 2 at worst in the testset of posts I was using.

1565708858_1BP1yj9evars2xjLc1Hw6icEg3BKJ.body:
>so my understanding is that text/links are automatically seeded, but images/webs etc are not. Is this correct?

Basically what @arhipo said. On millchan the thumbnail and the original image are two separate things. The thumbnail is downloaded and seeded by you as soon as you see it, while the original is only downloaded(and seeded) if you click on the thumbnail to 'maximize' it. The `seed`-button refers to the original image not to the thumbnail.
In shot: Everything text is downloaded without you doing anything, the thumbnails as soon as you see them and the original images as soon as you click on either `seed` or the thumbnail.

> [russianspy](#comment_1_1A3LTcwaXGFQJb7KDN4rbgYzNFQdAWEXa9): Server errorErr: DatabaseError: database disk image is malformed in UiServer.py line 103 > UiRequest.py line 152 > UiConfigPlugin.py line 21 > ContentFilterPlugin.py line 216 > UiRequest.py line 358 > SiteManagerPlugin.py line 65 > SiteManager.py line 150 > Site.py line 54 > OptionalManagerPlugin.py line 61 > ContentManager.py line 34 > ContentDbDict.py line 18 > ContentDb.py line 112 > Db.py line 75 > DbCursor.py line 82

Do you get an white screen with just that error or is it some popup error?
The popup thing should be fixed with the rebuild that @ayra mentioned. If not, you likely need to backup your `users.json`, take note of what zites you currently have, shutdown ZeroNet, delete your ZeroNet-data folder, restart ZeroNet, shut it down again, swap the new `users.json` with your old one and finally start ZeroNet again. This, in general, will solve most of the issues you may run into. Alternatively you can add `db_mode = security` in your `zeronet.conf` file to lower the chances of that happening again.

1566248008_1KSUcqHRcq26pF5vJ2297jrNcAzkN.body:
>corner and select "rebuild database" and then "reload database" when finished.

`reload database` looks for and finds any changes in the `dbschema.json` file which is used to build the database from the files of the zite. `rebuild database` uses the currently known version of `dbschema.json` to rebuild the database. Doing `rebuild database` first and then `reload database` is pointless.

1567261498_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
I agree with much of what you said. Things need to change.

However I strongly disagree with saying Nofish is childish and calling it a day. People have reason they act the way they do.
I think you should think about and consider more of why he is and acts this way. Whether or not he 'means' it or actually is that way is difficult to tell, but I personally don't think he is.

The issue with this whole situation seems to be mostly a lack of communication on nofishs part.
Nofish doesn't have a big presence on here or anywhere else and doesn't really get personal, so it's difficult to judge why he acts this way. But he seems rather to himself and to prefer being 'silent neutral' over engaging in discussions.

The times I seen him interact, seem to me like he wants to distances himself from the ZeroNet community and maybe from the project itself. Which is kind of understandable since he, his personality and face is bound to this project; ZeroNet. This comes with a pretty hefty burden that many projects like this face: Among the many good things you'll intend to do with your project, you'll also enable all of the bad things.
Many things he, as a person, may dislike or hate(I'm guessing here):
- Providing a platform for Political extremists.
- Providing a platform for the extremists of Religion.
- Providing a platform for either of the above to plan and execute attacks(be it lethal or not).
- Providing a platform for pedophiles(be it pro or anti contact ones).
- Providing a platform to share and plan the abuse of children.
- Allow murderers/killers to share intel and sell their services.
- Allow rapists to upload and share their acts with anyone that asks, possibly encouraging them to do it more/again.

These are a subset of things he might find resentful and yet he will permit all of these and many more gruesome things.
This is a **really hard** ethical/moral situation he's in, regardless of what he believes in or are his politically ideals are, he has to permit the opposite of those and will be associated with it.
I have to stress that Nofish, like everyone else, is human: He has loved ones, a house, a family, relationships to other humans, a private life all of which he could either fall in bad faith with or outright loose.
Questions like: `Why are you supporting pedophiles?`, `Why didn't you stop [insert terrorist attack here]?` and similar are things that are likely to pop up among is inner circle of friends/family. These aren't even unreasonable things to ask, since: 'had he not made ZeroNet, none of that would've happened'. Regardless of whether or not he or this project is just, the attempt to explain or reason could very well cause those he cares about to turn away from him.

Distancing himself from ZeroNet is a way for him to minimize the harm, ~if~ when something horrible happens.

The other thing is that pride exists. ZeroNet has gotten fairly big and wide known. Your brain might work differently(or you think it would under these circumstances) and so you would ask for help and get others involved, but the fear of your first big thing and accomplishments; something you are proud of, being alienated, isolated and taken away from you bit by bit is very reasonable.

In short, I think Nofishs childish behavior is probably be explained by a mix of pride and fear for his future. Calling him childish and unreasonable/dismissive without (publicly) trying to understand/acknowledge  his motives and why he acts this way will do nothing at best.

Take ZeroMe for example Due to the way it is structured it is possible to have everyone, on a ZeroMe hub of your choosing, download and seed any image you want.

Child porn for better or for worse has horrible, possibly permanent, consequences for your private, public and professional life. In a lot of cases __regardless of context__.

> [randomshits](#comment_193_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): Even KopyKate has a potential exploit where someone can upload a bunch small videos and then plant child porn as the thumbnail  jpeg;base64 text string causing everyone who seeds the site to also seed the cp thumbnails  but like you said.

To be fair you could do that anywhere. There's even an effort to insert CP into the bitcoin blockchain on [millchan/b/](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1H5YxVHvcfKM4STjJwyjYaBe8qbPyR6EZr:b:9ea42cb5-fb15-4de0-a8c3-b7f25fb1af0a).
At some point it just turns into a game of semantics over what even is child porn. For example:
Imagine I have child porn and encrypt(say AES) it with a 20 characters long key. I now have ~3MB of random 1s and 0s(the encrypted file) and 20 chars of key. Which of these is the child porn now? The key? The 1s and 0s? Both? Neither?  
What if I use the best encryption that currently exists: XORing it with a string of 1s and 0s as big as the CP file itself. Now I have ~3MB of key and ~3MB of encrypted file. Now close your eyes and open them again. I just shuffled the key and the encrypted file. Which one is which? You can prove mathematically that you will not be able to tell them apart. So what now, which of these is the child porn now? The 'key'? The 'encrypted file'? Both? Neither?  
  
The question here is: At what point is the representation of CP no longer CP?  
  
The ZeroMe thing is a bit different in that it will store the actual `.jpg` file on everyones computer not some other representation(base64 inside of a json file in this case) of it (I'm not saying that makes it less valid of an issue, just that kopykates issue is a bit less 'real').

1570282298_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
> [emmet](#comment_6_1N4DSSHorDvEkDGkQfUhnnryYiTdtUW8hU): It's just an xfce Debian install with two xfce virtual machines running at all times.

This is not true. QubesOS is running a Xen hypervisor with an (in some sense) custom made and maintained fedora25 dom0 controller.  
I terms of recourse consumption it's really demanding. Especially hard disk writes(often random ones, so a SLC(=fast) SSD will do you a lot of favors here) and CPU usage. Depending on how you want to set it up RAM is also a big deal, I'd say to aim for 8GB or above for an acceptable experience. But there's basically zero GPU usage, so you can probably get away with the integrated GPUs some CPUs have.

If you want to do a moderation system for a merger zite, you can take a look at [this](https://gitgud.io/millchan/merger/issues/5)(Clearnet) issue on the millchan merger repo, where I outlined a working moderation system that supports 'hierarchical permissions' (so admin(can do anything), moderators(can edit user data), volunteers(can overwrite what is displayed by the js of the zite)) and takes the current limitations of ZeroNet into account, while still being able to be as abstracted away from the user(be it mod or regular user) as one would expect.

I can elaborate this here, if you want.

The original proposal on the millchan repo should still work, but an extended and generalized version of it, I've been working on might be what you want.
I did a more detailed write up on it on [this](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/issues/view/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/12@1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC) ZeroNet issue where I reported that ZeroNet does not currently consider nested includes when checking for valid signer addresses for files.

1576059419_1F599yb2J8DmRn8nAxyN7e9MRuaU6.body:
Disclaimer: I am the owner of PedoHub.  
  
> [nickwa](#comment_474_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj):  Like I said, I don't know entirely why the hub's are a thing(waiting till somebody here schools me on that).

Because of the way they are implemented, zite(=ZeroNet site) owners are basically gods. They can add, remove, delete and alter any content on their zite(this includes user content). They have absolute power on their zite. The idea of Hubs(merger zites) is to separate the zite from the actual data/content of that zite, so their purpose is to take the control away from the developer of the zite you're on and give it to whoever you trust the most. Take ZeroMe for example, the interface/gui(the page that you can see) is under the address `1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH`. But your data is not there, it's stored on another zite(the hub you choose to join when registering).
This has multiple benefits, since the ZeroMe dev, who has control over the html/js that your computer runs, cannot modify your data and the hub owner, who has no control over the html/js that your computer runs, could modify your data.
So if you like ZeroMe, but notice that your hub is currently censoring you, you can just choose one of the many others out there and move to that and continue to speak freely.

On a side note: Another benefit of hubs is that data is not all in one place, so you can actually choose what required data(that is data that is downloaded automatically) to download instead of having to download everything. This is part of the reason why PedoHub even exists, to keep people from posting child porn on the regular hubs.

> [selfsigned](#comment_11_1F599yb2J8DmRn8nAxyN7e9MRuaU6QZfkZ): As i pointed, i didn't even ensured what is inside that HUB; but name is not that much friendly to want to look at all. [...] About the junk data inside, as i didn't look i could not confirm which kind of data where downloaded.

There is nothing illegal on the index page of PedoHub, if you still have the link you maybe want to give it a read.
From the `I just got here by accident. Am I in legal trouble` section:
```
No, you are not.
While this hub is likely to contain images that are illegal in many countries, files are only downloaded to your computer if they are needed.
This means, that images will get onto your machine, only if you click on them within ZeroMe(or any other zite, that supports the ZeroMe merger hubs).
Just viewing this page is not illegal. Using this hub or just seeding it to read the posts made by users of this hub is also not illegal as long, as you are careful with the images in those posts. 
```
Note that for reasons outside my control(because I only control the hub, not ZeroMe) avatar images are also considered required by ZeroMe and will be downloaded automatically, but at the time of this writing, nobody has an avatar image that is illegal.

>As i tried to point out, when you MERGE you have 0 control of what the fuck you are doing at all, just accept or ignore.

That's not true, if a zite wants to add a merger zite(=hub) a prompt will be displayed to you asking you to add the new zite. What can happen though, is that your browser opens the link to a file in a new tab and because link to a file on a hub that you don't have is the same as a link to a file on a zite you don't have ZeroNet will start to download the zite like it would with any other ZeroNet link you put into your browser.

> [nickwa](#comment_472_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): To access that person's profile, you need to usually merge with a hub.

I'm not sure if you mean the right thing. You only need to visit a hub once. ZeroNet will recognize automatically that it is a ZeroMe Merger and allow every zite you gave the `merger:ZeroMe` permission to read it.
>I am just guessing, might of been a trap. I don't know entirely how some people made their own "hubs", but I know it can be done to make their own.

On ZeroHello you can press the hamburger menu next to any ZeroMe hub and press clone to make your own hub.

> [selfsigned](#comment_10_1F599yb2J8DmRn8nAxyN7e9MRuaU6QZfkZ): So, the only point of view here is that I entered just 1 person with data, and this fcking person hosts data in such pedoHUB and I just granted access to a HUB that  i may not really need at all to enter "just the profile"?

The profile of each user is only stored in their hub, so you need to download the hub to see it, however not all data of a user is stored on the hub they're on. When you make a comment under a ZeroMe post, that comment is stored twice, once on the hub your on and once on the hub where the post you commented under was stored. In the last case a reference to the address of your hub is also stored. This way a user who stumbles across your comment but doesn't have your hub can still read your comment and is able to get to your profile(by downloading the referenced hub)

1576345092_1T4nUY5eDwwMk3zFjh27ZQCqkVpPx.body: Some are. You can see your current connections on the [Stats page](/Stats).

You can start ZeroNet with the `--force_encryption` flag or add `force_encryption` into your `zeronet.conf` file(it's in your ZeroNet folder). If it doesn't exist you can create a new one and put the following in it:
```
[global]
force_encryption
```
Although you should consider that encryption only hides the content of your internet connections. Everyone can see that you are using ZeroNet, if you have to conceal this as well use the Tor only mode, by either adding `tor = always` and `trackers_proxy = tor` to the config file or starting ZeroNet with the `--tor always` **and** `--trackers_proxy tor` flag.
